description: From Middle English water boarde, waterbord, equivalent to water +‎ board. Compare West Frisian wetterboard (“waterboard”), Dutch waterbord (“waterboard”), German Wassertafel (“waterboard”), Danish vandbræt (“waterboard”), Swedish vattenbräda (“waterboard”), Icelandic vatnsbretti (“waterboard”).

entries.meaning: A board set up to windward in a boat, to keep out water.
A public commission charged with overseeing water quality in a particular area.

verbs.description: waterboard (third-person singular simple present waterboards, present participle waterboarding, simple past and past participle waterboarded)

entries.meaning: To subject to waterboarding, to pour water over a cloth covering the face and breathing passages of an immobilized captive.
examples: We waterboarded the suspect, but he refused to confess.
